# Hectare

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Hectare  
---  
[Unit system](/wiki/System_of_measurement "System of measurement") | [non-SI](/wiki/Non-SI_units_mentioned_in_the_SI "Non-SI units mentioned in the SI") [metric system](/wiki/Metric_system "Metric system")  
Unit of | Area  
Symbol | ha   
In [SI base units](/wiki/SI_base_unit "SI base unit"): | 1 ha = 104 m2  
  
The **hectare** ([/ˈhɛktɛər, -tɑːr/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English"); [SI](/wiki/SI "SI") symbol: ha) is an SI accepted [metric
system](/wiki/Metric_system "Metric system") unit of [area](/wiki/Area "Area")
equal to 100 [ares](/wiki/Hectare#Are "Hectare") (10,000 m2) or 1 square
[hectometre](/wiki/Hectometre "Hectometre") (hm2) and primarily used in the
measurement of land as a metric replacement for the imperial [acre](/wiki/Acre
"Acre").[1] An acre is about 0.405 hectare and one hectare contains about 2.47
acres.

In 1795, when the metric system was introduced, the "are" was defined as 100
[square metres](/wiki/Square_metre "Square metre") and the hectare
("[hecto-](/wiki/Hecto- "Hecto-")" \+ "are") was thus 100 "ares" or ​1⁄100
km2. When the metric system was further rationalised in 1960, resulting in the
[International System of Units](/wiki/International_System_of_Units
"International System of Units") (SI), the _are_ was not included as a
recognised unit. The hectare, however, remains as a non-SI unit accepted for
use with the SI units, mentioned in Section 4.1 of the SI Brochure as a unit
whose use is "expected to continue indefinitely".[1]

Comparison of [area units](/wiki/Template:Convert/list_of_units/area "Template:Convert/list of units/area") Unit | SI  
---|---

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

The metric system of measurement was first given a legal basis in 1795 by the
[French Revolutionary](/wiki/French_Revolution "French Revolution")
government. The law of [18 Germinal, Year
III](/wiki/French_Republican_Calendar "French Republican Calendar") (7 April
1795) defined five units of measure:[2]

  * The [metre](/wiki/Metre "Metre") for length
  * The [are](/wiki/Hectare#Are "Hectare") (100 m2) for area [of land]
  * The [stère](/wiki/Stere "Stere") (1 m3) for volume of stacked firewood[3]
  * The [litre](/wiki/Litre "Litre") (1 dm3) for volumes of liquid
  * The gram for mass

Although the law defined the length of the metre, there was no practical way
of accurately measuring the metre (and hence the _are_) until 1799 when the
first standard metre was manufactured and adopted.

The standard metre remained in the custody of successive French governments
until 1875 when, under the [Convention of the Metre](/wiki/Metre_Convention
"Metre Convention"), its supervision passed into international control under
the auspices of the [General Conference on Weights and
Measures](/wiki/General_Conference_on_Weights_and_Measures "General Conference
on Weights and Measures") (CGPM). At the first meeting of the CGPM in 1889
when a new standard metre, manufactured by [Johnson
Matthey](/wiki/Johnson_Matthey "Johnson Matthey") & Co of London[4] was
adopted, the _are_ and _hectare_ were automatically redefined.

In 1960, when the metric system was updated as the International System of
Units (SI), the _are_ did not receive international recognition. The
[International Committee for Weights and
Measures](/wiki/Comit%C3%A9_International_des_Poids_et_Mesures "Comité
International des Poids et Mesures") (CIPM) makes no mention of the _are_ in
the current (2006) definition of the SI, but classifies the hectare as a "Non-
SI unit accepted for use with the International System of Units"[5]

In 1972, the [European Economic Community](/wiki/European_Economic_Community
"European Economic Community") (EEC) passed directive 71/354/EEC,[6] which
catalogued the units of measure that might be used within the Community. The
units that were catalogued replicated the recommendations of the CGPM,
supplemented by a few other units including the _are_ (and implicitly the
_hectare_) whose use was limited to the measurement of land.

Many UK farmers, especially older ones, still use the [acre](/wiki/Acre
"Acre") for everyday calculations, and convert to hectares only for official
(especially European Union) paperwork. Farm fields can have very long
histories which are resistant to change, with names such as "the six acre
field" stretching back hundreds of years and across generations of family
farmers. Some younger agricultural workers are now beginning to think in
hectares as their "first language", though this is more typical of
professional consultants and managers than of traditional farming and land-
owning families, and in some circles may be viewed as a social class
indicator.

## Units[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Units")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Hectare_Diagram.svg/300px-
Hectare_Diagram.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Hectare_Diagram.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Hectare_Diagram.svg "Enlarge")

Definition of a _hectare_ and of an _are_.

The names _centiare_ , _deciare_ , _decare_ and _hectare_ are derived by
adding the standard [metric prefixes](/wiki/Metric_prefix "Metric prefix") to
the original base unit of area, the _are_.

### Centiare[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Centiare")]

The **centiare** is one square metre.

### Deciare[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Deciare")]

The **deciare** is ten square metres.

### Are[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section:
Are")]

The **are** ([/ɑːr/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")[7] or
[/ɛər/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")[8]) is a unit of area,
equal to 100 square metres (10 m × 10 m), used for measuring land area. It was
defined by older forms of the [metric system](/wiki/Metric_system "Metric
system"), but is now outside the modern [International System of
Units](/wiki/International_System_of_Units "International System of Units")
(SI).[9] It is still commonly used in colloquial speech to measure real
estate, in particular in Indonesia, India, and in various European countries.

In [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language") and other languages of
the former [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), the _are_ is
called _sotka_ (Russian: сотка: 'a hundred', i.e. 100 m2). It is used to
describe the size of suburban [dacha](/wiki/Dacha "Dacha") or [allotment
garden](/wiki/Allotment_garden "Allotment garden") plots or small city parks
where the hectare would be too large.

Etymologically, the word _are_ finds its roots in the
[Talmudic](/wiki/Talmudic "Talmudic") [Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic "Aramaic") word
ארעא (_araa_), meaning "land".[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Decare[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Decare")]

The **decare** ([/ˈdɛkɑːr, -ɛər/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"))
is derived from _[deca](/wiki/Deca- "Deca-")_ and _[are](/wiki/Hectare#Are
"Hectare")_ , and is equal to 10 ares or 1000 square metres. It is used in
Norway[10] and in the former [Ottoman](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire")
areas of the Middle East and the Balkans (Bulgaria)[11] as a measure of land
area. Instead of the name "decare", the names of traditional land measures are
usually used, redefined as one decare:

  * [Stremma](/wiki/Stremma "Stremma") in Greece[12]
  * [Dunam](/wiki/Dunam "Dunam"), dunum, donum, or dönüm in Israel, Palestine, Jordan, Lebanon, Syria and Turkey[13]
  * Mål is sometimes used for decare in Norway, from the old measure of about the same area.

### Hectare[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Hectare")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Trafalgar_Square%2C_London_2_-_Jun_2009.jpg/300px-
Trafalgar_Square%2C_London_2_-_Jun_2009.jpg)](/wiki/File:Trafalgar_Square,_London_2_-_Jun_2009.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Trafalgar_Square,_London_2_-_Jun_2009.jpg "Enlarge")

[Trafalgar Square](/wiki/Trafalgar_Square "Trafalgar Square") has an area of
about one hectare.[14]

The **hectare** ([/ˈhɛktɛər, -tɑːr/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English")[15]), although not a unit of SI, is the only named unit of
area that is [accepted for use within the SI](/wiki/Non-
SI_units_mentioned_in_the_SI#Units_officially_accepted_for_use_with_the_SI
"Non-SI units mentioned in the SI").[16] In practice the hectare is fully
derived from the SI, being equivalent to a square hectometre. It is widely
used throughout the world for the measurement of large areas of land, and it
is the legal unit of measure in domains concerned with land ownership,
planning, and [management](/wiki/Land_management "Land management"), including
law ([land deeds](/wiki/Deed "Deed")), agriculture, [forestry](/wiki/Forestry
"Forestry"), and [town planning](/wiki/Town_planning "Town planning")
throughout the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union").[17]
The United Kingdom,[18] United States, Burma,[19][20] and to some extent
Canada use the acre instead.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Some countries that underwent a general conversion from traditional
measurements to [metric](/wiki/Metric_system "Metric system") measurements
(e.g. Canada) required a resurvey when units of measure in legal descriptions
relating to land were converted to metric units.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Others,
such as South Africa, published conversion factors which were to be used
particularly "when preparing consolidation diagrams by compilation".[21]

In many countries, metrication redefined or clarified existing measures in
terms of metric units. The following legacy units of area have been redefined
as being equal to one hectare:[22]

  * _[Jerib](/wiki/Jerib "Jerib")_ in Iran
  * _[Djerib](/wiki/Jerib "Jerib")_ in Turkey[23]
  * _Gong Qing_ (公頃/公顷 – gōngqǐng) in Hong Kong / mainland China
  * _[Manzana](/wiki/Manzana_\(unit\) "Manzana \(unit\)")_ in Argentina
  * _[Bunder](/wiki/Bunder "Bunder")_ in The Netherlands (until 1937)[24][25]

## Conversions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Conversions")]

**Metric and imperial/US customary comparisons**  
---  
**Unit** | **Symbol** | **Metric equivalents** | **Imperial/US customary equivalents**  
centiare | ca |  | 1 m2 | 0.01 a | 1.19599 [sq yd](/wiki/Square_yard "Square yard")  
are | a[26] | 100 ca | 100 m2 | 0.01 ha | 3.95369 [perches](/wiki/Perch_\(unit\) "Perch \(unit\)")  
decare | daa | 10 a | 1,000 m2 | 0.1 ha | 0.98842 [roods](/wiki/Rood_\(unit\) "Rood \(unit\)")  
**hectare** | **ha**[1] | **100 a** | **10,000 m 2** | **0.01 km 2** | **2.471 acres**[27]  
square kilometre | km2 | 100 ha | 1,000,000 m2 |  | 0.38610 [sq mi](/wiki/Square_mile "Square mile")  
  
The most commonly used units are in **bold**.

One hectare is also equivalent to:

  * 1 square hectometre
  * 15 [mǔ](/wiki/Chinese_units_of_measurement#Area "Chinese units of measurement") or 0.15 qǐng[28]
  * 10 [dunam](/wiki/Dunam "Dunam") or dönüm (Middle East)[29]
  * 10 [stremmata](/wiki/Stremma "Stremma") (Greece)
  * 6.25 [rai](/wiki/Rai_\(unit\) "Rai \(unit\)") (Thailand)[30]
  * ≈ 1.008 [chō](/wiki/Tsubo_\(unit\) "Tsubo \(unit\)") (Japan)
  * ≈ 2.381 [feddan](/wiki/Feddan "Feddan") (Egypt)

## Visualising a
hectare[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section:
Visualising a hectare")]

### International rugby
pitch[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section:
International rugby pitch")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Hamilton_03.jpg/220px-
Hamilton_03.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hamilton_03.jpg) [](/wiki/File:Hamilton_03.jpg
"Enlarge") [Waikato Stadium](/wiki/Waikato_Stadium "Waikato Stadium") –
Hamilton, New Zealand
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Rugbyfield.svg/220px-
Rugbyfield.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Rugbyfield.svg) [](/wiki/File:Rugbyfield.svg
"Enlarge") The maximum playing area of an international-sized rugby union
pitch is about one hectare On an international [rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union
"Rugby union") field the goal lines are up to 100 metres apart. Behind the
goal line is the in-goal area (which is also a playing area). This area
extends between 10 and 22 metres behind the goal line, giving a maximum length
of 144 metres for the playing area. The maximum width of the pitch is 70
metres, giving a maximum playing area of 10,080 square metres or 1.008
hectares.[31]  
---  
  
### Statue of Liberty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Statue of Liberty")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Freiheitsstatue_NYC_full.jpg/150px-
Freiheitsstatue_NYC_full.jpg)](/wiki/File:Freiheitsstatue_NYC_full.jpg)
[](/wiki/File:Freiheitsstatue_NYC_full.jpg "Enlarge") [The Statue of
Liberty](/wiki/The_Statue_of_Liberty "The Statue of Liberty") – [New York
Harbor](/wiki/New_York_Harbor "New York Harbor")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/StatueOfLibertyFootprint.svg/220px-
StatueOfLibertyFootprint.svg.png)](/wiki/File:StatueOfLibertyFootprint.svg)
[](/wiki/File:StatueOfLibertyFootprint.svg "Enlarge") The Statue of Liberty
occupies a square of land with an area of one hectare [40°41′21″N 74°2′40″W﻿ /
﻿40.68917°N 74.04444°W﻿ / 40.68917; -74.04444﻿ (Statue of
Liberty)](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Hectare&params=40_41_21_N_74_2_40_W_&title=Statue+of+Liberty)
The [Statue of Liberty](/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty "Statue of Liberty"), a gift
from the French people to the American people dedicated on 28 October 1886 to
commemorate the hundredth anniversary of the [French](/wiki/French_Revolution
"French Revolution") and [American Revolutions](/wiki/American_Revolution
"American Revolution"), is located on [Liberty Island](/wiki/Liberty_Island
"Liberty Island") at the entrance to [New York Harbor](/wiki/New_York_Harbor
"New York Harbor"). Its base is built on eighteenth-century fortifications.
The distance between the [apex](/wiki/Apex_\(geometry\) "Apex \(geometry\)")
of the [bastions](/wiki/Bastion "Bastion") in the front of the base to those
at the back (where the entrance to the statue is located) is approximately 100
m while the distance between the apexes of the left-hand and right-hand
bastions is a little under 100 m. Thus, if a square were to enscribe the
bastions, it would have sides of approximately 100 m, giving it an area of one
hectare.  
---  
  
### Interior of all-weather athletics
track[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hectare&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section:
Interior of all-weather athletics track")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Hansen_Field.JPG/200px-
Hansen_Field.JPG)](/wiki/File:Hansen_Field.JPG) [](/wiki/File:Hansen_Field.JPG
"Enlarge") Hansen Field at [Western Illinois
University](/wiki/Western_Illinois_University "Western Illinois University")
in [Macomb](/wiki/Macomb,_Illinois "Macomb, Illinois"), Illinois incorporates
an [all-weather running track](/wiki/All-weather_running_track "All-weather
running track")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Piste_athl%C3%A9tisme-
en.svg/220px-Piste_athl%C3%A9tisme-
en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Piste_athl%C3%A9tisme-en.svg)
[](/wiki/File:Piste_athl%C3%A9tisme-en.svg "Enlarge") The grass in the centre
of a standard athletic track is a little over one hectare in extent Athletics
tracks are found in almost every country of the world. Although many tracks
consist of markings on a field of suitable size, where funds permit,
specialist all-weather tracks have a rubberized artificial running surface
with a grass interior (as shown in the picture and diagram). The perimeter of
the inside kerb of the track is a little under 400 metres, as the actual
length of the track is measured 300 mm from the inside kerb.[32] The IAAF
specifications state that the radius of the kerb is 36.5 m, from which it can
be calculated that the area inside the kerb is 1.035 ha.[a] The soccer field
often found inside is normally 105×70 m, that is 0.73 hectares.
